# Do Employees Cheer for Private Equity? The Heterogeneous Effects of Buyouts on Job Qualit!  

February 8, 2022  

# Abstract  

We show that private equity leveraged buyouts (LBOs) reduce perceived job quality despite not impacting average base pay. This appears to reflect higher risk for employees. Both job quality and employee incentive pay are more related to firm performance at private equity-owned companies than at public control firms, with $1\%$ higher deal IRR associated with $0.7\%$ more employee incentive pay. Also, higher leverage deals and employees with worse outside options and longer tenure drive the post-LBO satisfaction declines. Our results highlight how job quality is tied to job security and how ownership affects employees through mechanisms beyond base pay.  

Keywords: private equity, leveraged buyouts, job quality, employees, corporate culture, non-pecuniary amenities, implicit contracts  

JEL: G24, G32, J31, J32  

A worker's relationship with her employer involves far more than money. Company culture, commitment to work-life balance, and management are central to job quality but do not show up on a paycheck. Although employees at larger firms may never meet the firm owners, a growing literature has linked employee outcomes to ownership structure. In this paper, we explore the impact of private equity (PE) ownership on job quality.  

PE has a large footprint on the US economy, accounting for more than one-third of recent M&A transactions.2 The asset class has delivered strong financial returns to both investors and fund managers.3 These returns come from a combination of operational and capital structure changes.4 Although PE deals generate value for owners, their effect on employees - among a firm's most important stakeholders - is far from clear. One hypothesis is that PE investors create value in part by extracting surplus from employees by cutting amenities, reducing job security, and increasing demands on workers. Consistent with this, media reports highlight layoffs and oppressive working conditions after PE buyouts. Under that model, returns to investors come at the expense of employee well-being. An alternative is that the actions PE owners take to improve firm value might make employees happier. This could arise if PE owners relax capital constraints and allow needed investments (Boucly, Sraer, and Thesmar, 2011; Krishnan, Nandy, and Puri, 2015), turn around struggling firms (Johnston-Ross, Ma, and Puri, 2021; Cohn, Hotchkiss, and Towery, 2021), or perhaps even make active investments in employees which were forgone by myopic or capital-constrained prior owners (Edmans, 2011; Welch and Yoon, 2020).  

We test and help reconcile these contrasting predictions. We ask how buyouts affect employee perceptions of job quality, including not just compensation but also non-pecuniary amenities, and examine how any effects differ across both deal and employee types. To do so, we use employee reviews from the website Glassdoor and focus on dimensions that speak to the crucial intangibles of the employer-employee relationship: satisfaction with compensation, work-life balance, culture, and senior management, along with reported base salary and variable (i.e. performance) pay. We merge the Glassdoor firms to PE deals from Pitchbook and M&A transactions from Capital IQ. We further match the PE transactions to deal-level returns data from Stepstone, a large fund of funds. Our analysis dataset includes over three million reviews of jobs by employees currently working at 271,000 unique companies posted between 2008 and 2019.  

Employee review data offer several advantages over more standard datasets.  First, understanding job quality requires eliciting the opinions of workers themselves, who, as Guiso, Sapienza, and Zingales (2015) point out, offer a ground truth on firm culture that does not always align with how the firm advertises its own culture. Second, our data shed new light on earnings relative to administrative datasets such as those available at the U.s. Census Bureau.  The Glassdoor measures cover all compensation, including equity, both via reported salary and incentive pay. Third, our data allow us to measure not just pay but also the satisfaction with that pay, which is arguably most relevant for welfare. Existing research has validated Glassdoor employee review data, showing that it is informative about firm outcomes and representative of the U.S. wage distribution.6  

Our research design is a differences-in-differences model, using firm and industry-time fixed effects with never-PE-owned firms serving as controls. Although this design is common, it faces two identification challenges: selection of targets by PE firms, and selection of employees into leaving reviews.  We address the firm selection concern in four ways.  First, dynamic differences-in-differences event studies describe whether target firms appear to be on track towards the changes we observe. These show no pre-trends and a discontinuous change after the buyout. Second, we conduct a falsification test with canceled deals, which show no effects, suggesting that unobservable firm characteristics attracting PE investors do not drive our results. More generally, we show the observables that PE firms target do not drive our results. Third, most of our results are across deal or employee characteristics, which addresses many selection stories. Fourth, we show that our results survive a host of robustness checks, such as a matching estimator.  

Nonetheless, PE firms clearly do not pick targets at random. Our causality argument focuses on treatment effects for the treated, rather than externally validity to a random firm in the economy. We show that treated firms were not on track to the outcomes we observe and would have continued, at least in the medium term, on their pre-existing path in the absence of the LBO. This interpretation is important for social welfare as PE expands its footprint in the economy; even to the degree that target firms “need" LBOs because they are mismanaged, we shed light on how employee wellbeing relates to value creation in PE.  

Employee selection is the second challenge. People visit the Glassdoor website for a reason, namely to read and write company reviews. Our key assumption is that whatever makes a person write a review at an LBO target is the same as what makes them write a review at a control firm. To mitigate the influence of selection, we consider only reviews by current employees, limiting bias from laid-off employees. We also aggregate reviews to company-quarter averages, which addresses potential buyout-induced changes in the number of reviewers. Beyond that, we show that changes in the number and composition of reviewers around the buyout are in practice small and insignificant, and our results are not driven by changes in either tail of the distribution. Fortunately, the structure of the Glassdoor site is designed to generate quality reviews, both because reviews are anonymous, which reduces any incentive to misrepresent, and because Glassdoor requires contributing a review in order to view reviews on the platform, which reduces both selection bias and the polarization inherent in online reviews (Marinescu et al., 2018).  

We show that after an LBO, employee satisfaction with compensation declines by 0.083 points on a one-to-five scale, with a slightly larger negative effect on satisfaction with firm culture and slightly smaller negative effects on satisfaction with work-life balance and senior management. This relationship is economically meaningful. For example, it is $57\%$ larger than the reported compensation satisfaction gap between reviewers in college degree-requiring jobs and those in high school-requiring jobs. We also find discontinuous increases in the usage of terms such as 'cost-cutting’ and ‘uncertainty’ around the deal data, providing support for both causality and specific operational mechanisms. However, despite significant declines in reported satisfaction with compensation, we can rule out large decreases in average pay.  

One important mechanism for the decline in satisfaction with compensation is higher risk. LBOs increase the risk employees face through several channels, ranging from higher-powered incentives to dramatically higher firm leverage. First, LBOs lead to large increases in managerial incentive pay. These increases are consistent with research showing manager incentives are a key part of value creation (Gompers, Kaplan, and Mukharlyamov, 2016).  

Second, higher leverage deals have far more negative effects on job quality along all dimensions, with moderate-to-no effect for relatively low leverage deals. The strong relationship for leverage contrasts with weak relationships for other deal characteristics such as size and deal type (public-to-private, corporate divestiture, and vanilla). Leverage is also more important than whether a deal was associated with large one-time layoffs, which we examine using a novel panel of LinkedIn profile information collected specifically for our target firms. While there is evidence of significant one-time layoffs at the time of many buyouts, both the satisfaction and leverage results appear independent of layoffs. Although we cannot identify a causal effect of leverage, we document that following public firm recapitalizations, a situation outside PE where firms quickly take on large amounts of new debt while simultaneously buying back shares or issuing large dividends, we also see satisfaction with compensation decreasing in new leverage.  

Third, we document an increase in the degree to which firm returns are passed through to employees. Our use of deal-level cash flows from StepStone's SPI database makes us, to our knowledge, the first paper to link PE returns to employee welfare. The best-performing PE deals are associated with happier employees across dimensions, implying that the returns in these deals are not earned at the expense of employees. Although base pay remains flat, a $1\%$ higher deal IRR mapsto $0.7\%$ more incentive pay. This aligns with previous literature showing firm performance to be positively associated with employee satisfaction (Verwijmeren and Derwall, 2010; Edmans, 2011; Bae, Kang, and Wang, 2011; Edmans, Li, and Zhang, 2014; Guiso, Sapienza, and Zingales, 2015; Green et al., 2019). Digging deeper, we show that the performance satisfaction relationship is three times stronger for PE targets than for public firms. This suggests employees at LBO targets are dramatically more exposed to the firm's fortunes. Although they are strongly correlated ex-post, employee pre-deal satisfaction levels do not robustly predict investor returns.  

We connect our results to models of ownership structure and employee-firm risk sharing such as Berk, Stanton, and Zechner (2010). In these models, firms commit to low leverage and stable pay for employees in order to attract talent. Ex-post, firms may have an incentive to fire employees, increase leverage, or otherwise default on that commitment. Through the lens of the Shleifer and Summers (1988) breach-of-implicit-contract mechanism, PE firms′ actions to increase employee risk bearing may be responding to that incentive by reneging on those implicit contracts. We test the predictions of this mechanism. First, greater risk can explain the reduction in pay satisfaction with no reduction in pay; employees view the loss of stability as a real cost and demand compensating wage differentials. Second, we show the effects are entirely driven by longer-tenure, pre-deal hires, who presumably were the former beneficiaries of any implicit guarantees. Third, we show effects are strongest among workers with the largest costs of unemployment, such as those in high unemployment industries.  

This paper contributes to the literature on the conflicts of interest between labor and capital (Atanassov and Kim, 2009). We show for the first time how ownership changes affect workers' non-pecuniary amenities and perception of firm culture. While the literature has separately studied how corporate ownership structures affect firm outcomes (e.g. Maksimovic and Phillips (2008), Cremers, Nair, and John (2009), Bena and Li (2014)) and the importance of culture, management, and other non-wage amenities (e.g. Levit and Malenko (2016)), rarely have they been examined together. Our findings are consistent with the conclusion of Guiso, Sapienza, and Zingales (2015) that “a focus towards shareholders’ value-maximization undermines the ability of a company to sustain a high level of integrity capital,’ because LBOs imply a transition to higher-powered incentives to maximize short-term profit (Kaplan and Stromberg, 2009). Related work that touches more broadly on employee welfare around acquisitions or takeovers includes Pontiff, Shleifer, and Weisbach (1990), Pagano and Volpin (2005), John, Knyazeva, and Knyazeva (2015), and Dessaint, Golubov, and Volpin (2017).  

Our paper joins studies of how PE ownership affects workers, which includes Boucly, Sraer, and Thesmar (2011) and Davis et al. (2014) on the number of employees, Cohn, Nestoriak, and Wardlaw (2021) on workplace safety, Olsson and Tag (2017) on unemployment incidence at LBO targets in Sweden, Fang, Goldman, and Roulet (2021) on wage gaps at LBO targets in France, and Antoni, Maug, and Obernberger (2019) on employment and wages at LBO targets in Germany. Our paper extends this work in at least four ways. First, we shed new light on the importance of non-pecuniary amenities such as employees’ perceptions of firm culture. Non-pecuniary job amenities are an important but largely unstudied and not fully priced dimension of the economy (Mas and Pallais, 2017; Lins, Servaes, and Tamayo, 2017; Lamadon, Mogstad, and Setzler, 2019). Second, our performance pay measure includes stock option grants and other types of variable pay. Third, we study the real effects of U.s. buyouts on a large and representative sample. As Morris and Phalippou (2020) note, the literature on PE ownership has generally used small and selected samples restricted to a single industry or European country with markedly different labor laws from the U.S. Finally, we shed light on the important role of risk sharing. In contemporaneous work, Lambert, Moreno, Phalippou, and Scivoletto (2021) also study PE and employee satisfaction, but focus on the role of public-to-private transactions, PE firm fixed effects, and the relationship between scores and comment text. Finally, this paper is also related to the growing emphasis that institutional investors place on ESG (Barber, Morse, and Yasuda, 2021; Lins, Servaes, and Tamayo, 2017), one component of which is employee well-being.  

### Data Sources and Summary Statistics  

We take data from several sources. Employee-level job quality variables are from Glassdoor reviews. The companies in Glassdoor are matched to PE deals from Pitchbook, employment histories from LinkedIn, and investor returns from Stepstone. We use CRSP return data, CapitalIQ M&A deals, Compustat accounting data, and Preqin ESG data for supplemental analysis.  

Employee Review  Data.  We begin  with comprehensive employee review data from Glassdoor.com between the platform's January 2008 inception and 2019, the year before the COVID-19 pandemic. These data cover almost all major companies and contain measures of employee satisfaction and reported pay and benefits, as well as the reviewer's job title, tenure, employment status, and location. Figure 1 offers an example of one of the reviews that composes the underlying data. We hover the mouse over the overall rating (a two out of a maximum of five) to view the dimension ratings. This reviewer gave Dell a one on Career Opportunities but a four on Compensation & Benefits.  

Why do people review on Glassdoor? They are likely usually searching for jobs, though they may also simply be interested in knowing more about their own company or another one. Glassdoor employs a give-to-get model, where a review must be entered in order to view the reviews on the website. This reduces the selection bias and polarization that are inherent in online reviews (Marinescu et al., 2018). Evidence of this is the fact that the distributions of the four ratings exhibit central tendency, shown in Appendix Figure A.1. For example, the mean Senior Management rating is 3.4 with a standard deviation of 1.4 (recall that the range is one to five).  

Nonetheless, reviewers are not randomly drawn from employees, a selection bias that poses a challenge to all survey-based papers. In our analysis, we make the key assumption that whatever makes a person write a review at an LBO target is the same as what makes them write a review at a control firm. We take several steps to test this assumption and ensure our results are robust to violations of it. First, we address potential variation in the number of reviews at a company over time by performing analysis at the company-quarter level or the company-quarter-cohort level (for example, long-tenured employees at a firm in a quarter). Second, we drop former employees, the most obvious source of bias, although our results persist in that cohort. Third, most of our analysis focuses on heterogeneity interactions, which mitigates concerns about selection, since we are, for example, comparing longer- to shorter-tenured workers at a PE-target relative to that same gap at a non-target. Fourth, we replicate our key analysis with controls for key observable employee characteristics. Finally, in practice, we do not see significant changes in the number or composition of workers giving reviews around buyouts (discussed below).  

Much of the existing research on how PE affects employees uses administrative sources, in particular the employee-employer panels available at the U.s. Census Bureau and similar institutions in other countries. The major advantage of these sources is that they do not face the problem of selection into reviewing. However, employee reviews and Glassdoor data specifically offer insights that are not available elsewhere, and in fact address precisely the weaknesses of traditional administrative data. First, they shed light on corporate culture and other non-pecuniary amenities, which are completely absent from Census data. Second, they contain information about performance pay, including stock compensation and benefits, while Census contains only base salaries. Third, observations are identified by the day and thus are “real time’ while the Census wage data are annual. Fourth, we observe granular occupation data, while the Census data lack occupation information. Finally, Glassdoor data may be linked to proprietary information such as our deal-level returns data, while Census data are tightly sequestered.  

In using the Glassdoor data, we consider only U.s.-based current employees of U.S. companies, yielding a final sample of 3,300,000 reviews from 271,000 companies.7 For these reviews, we focus primarily on seven dimensions. Four measure employee satisfaction with Compensation & Benefits, Culture & Values, Senior Management, and Work-Life Balance. We abbreviate the first two of these to “compensation” and “culture” for parsimony and because we find no effects on benefits when considered separately. These measures are quantified in numeric ratings, which range from one (worst) to five (best). The other three dimensions concern reported pay: base salary, variable pay, and an indicator for any variable pay. Variable pay, also called "performance pay,” includes bonuses, stock options, profit-sharing plans, and sales commissions, all of which are reported separately. Table 1 Panel A summarizes these ratings. We present a correlation matrix across the seven measures (plus benefits ratings) in Appendix Table A.1; the dimensions are correlated with one another in intuitive ways, but they each contain independent information.8  

Existing literature establishes that Glassdoor review data are both informative about firm outcomes and representative of the labor market, albeit somewhat skewed toward skilled occupations. Karabarbounis and Pinto (2018) show that the wage distribution of Glassdoor reviewers is consistent with external data from the U.S. Census Bureau. Sockin and Sockin (2019) show pay representativeness at the industry level, and Martellini, Schoellman, and Sockin (2021) document external validity of earnings using Department of Education college earnings data.  Comparing the average job satisfaction level between Glassdoor and the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth 1997, Sockin (2021) finds statistically significant correlations of nearly one-half across industries and occupations. Glassdoor reviews predict stock returns (Green et al., 2019; Sheng, 2019), operating performance (Huang, Li, and Markov, 2020), and firm financing (Chemmanur, Rajaiya, and Sheng, 2019). Lee et al. (2020) show that the reviews react to corporate events such as scandals. In sum, we are confident that the ratings offer reasonably truthful information about the state of the company.  

The Glassdoor data include reviewers’ tenure and job title, which we use to infer reviewer characteristics. These are summarized in Table 1 Panel B. The data contain new hires and veteran employees, with $25\%$ of employees working no more than one year at the firm, $29\%$ one to three years, $19\%$ three to five years, and $26\%$ five or more. We infer workers′ roles using their reported job titles. Text matching reveals that one out of six has a job title identifying them as a manager. We merge job titles to OCC codes using the mapping in Atalay et al. (2020).? About $14\%$ of the matched raters are in jobs that typically require no more than a year of work experience, while at the other end of the spectrum $23\%$ are in jobs requiring more than five years of experience. The majority $(76\%)$ are in jobs that typically require a college degree, while $18\%$ are in jobs that do not and the remaining $6\%$ are in jobs that require a Masters? or Professional degree. Finally, we use data from textual comments in the reviews, which we describe below.  

We construct company-quarter level variables using the review-level information. Although users can leave multiple reviews, the vast majority do not and so we abstract from reviewer identity. For the outcomes of satisfaction ratings, pay, and the textual indicators we take the average of reviews in the company quarter (the results are robust to using the median). For worker characteristics such as tenure or education, which we employ as right-hand-side variables for heterogeneity analysis, we split the sample at logical break points (e.g., jobs that require a college degree versus those that do not) and then calculate the average company-quarter level outcome separately for each group.  

PE and Acquisition Deal Data.  To obtain PE deal information, we manually match Glassdoor firms to PE deal targets in the Pitchbook database. We focus on targets based in the U.S. with a transaction date between 2010 and 2016 that have Glassdoor reviews on either side of the deal. PitchBook is widely regarded as one of the most comprehensive PE databases and is especially strong for the U.s. data and the most recent decade. We drop non-U.S. deals, secondary transactions (where company ownership is transferred between two PE investors), PIPEs and other investments in companies that were not taken private, and debt-only deals. This gives us a total of 7,701 deals.  

Within this sample, we consider three mutually exclusive PE business models. The first is 3,572 leveraged buyouts (LBOs). In an LBO, a PE fund takes a controlling stake in the target company. The PE firm borrows most of the money needed to purchase the company, but it organizes the transaction so that the debt is placed on the target company's balance sheet. That is, the target company owes the money used to purchase it, not the PE fund. The second group is 484 management buyouts (MBOs). In an MBO, the existing managers of a company purchase a controlling interest with the help of a PE firm. MBOs typically increase company leverage as well, but tend to be in the lower part of the LBO leverage distribution.1o The third group is 2,934 growth equity investments. Growth equity is closer to venture capital but for later-stage companies, and involves the PE firm taking a non-controlling stake in a company. Here, the cash from the investment goes to the company rather than to selling shareholders. We retain only a company's first deal in each of these three groups. 11  

Our main analysis focuses on LBOs, which are at a conceptual level the strongest PE treatment. We divide LBOs into three mutually exclusive categories based on Pitchbook's deal classification scheme: public-to-private deals, corporate divestitures, and ‘vanilla’ LBOs. In a public-to-private deal, PE investors purchase and take private a public company. Although small in number, these deals account for many of our reviews as the target companies tend to be large. Corporate divestitures occur when a PE firm acquires a subsidiary of a corporation, and either holds it as a standalone firm or rolls it into another existing company. They have significant cultural and management implications because they typically cause the corporate form to change from a diversified conglomerate to a more focused firm. We define a vanilla LBO as any other PE purchase of a standalone, privately held company.  

We matched 2,762 $(77\%)$ of the qualifying LBOs to Glassdoor companies, 405 of the MBOs $(84\%)$ , and 1,927 of the growth equity deals $(66\%)$ . In our main analysis, we restrict to the 1,371 LBO, 178 MBO, and 700 growth equity deals within these matched samples that have at least one review by current employees in both pre- and post-deal periods. Table 1 Panel C provides summary statistics about the final sample of matched LBOs that are used in our analysis. Appendix Table A.2 contains summary statistics about the growth equity and MBO sample. Appendix Table A.3 compares deal characteristics across all Pitchbook deals, Glassdoor matched deals, and our analysis sample. The matched deals are reasonably representative of the full dataset. They have a similar industry breakdown; for example, $16\%$ $(15\%)$ of deals in our matched (full) sample are in healthcare.12 Figure 2 shows that the matched deals are distributed relatively uniformly across our sample period. Overall, we believe our data are among the most representative of PE's overall role in the U.S. economy that researchers studying operational outcomes have employed to date.  

To beter understand the role of employee departures around LBOs, we obtain LinkedIn data from the analytics firm LIX on all employees who ever worked for a subset of the LBO target companies. We restrict this research to the 618 targets in the LBO analysis sample that have both (a) at least five reviews; and (b) current employee reviews before and after the deal. We match  

381 firms and record LinkedIn job titles and years for 457,087 of those firms’ employees. We use this to create a firm-year panel of departure and hiring rates. For example, the departure rate is the number of users reporting a final year of employment in year $t$ , divided by the number of users reporting employment at the company in year $t$ 13  

Investor Return Data.  We use investor return data from Stepstone Group, which has built its SPI database while providing fund-of-fund and advisory services in private markets since 2006. These data come from performing due diligence and monitoring investments, similar to other academic sources of deal-level PE return data (Robinson and Sensoy, 2013; Degeorge, Martin, and Phalippou, 2016; Braun, Jenkinson, and Stoff, 2017). Stepstone requires fund managers to report returns from all deals and reconcile them with fund-level performance, which mitigates the bias towards more successful deals that appears in some datasets. We use deal-level internal rate of return (IRR), total value multiple (TVM), and public market equivalents (PMEs), with the latter being calculated against the industry-specific Russell 2000 Indexes using reported cash fows following Kaplan and Schoar (2005). As with Glassdoor ratings, we measure returns at or before March 2020 to avoid the confounding effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.14  

Wematch $26\%$ (351) LBOs in our main sample to SPI, a proportion broadly consistent with SPI's coverage of the LBO universe. Summary statistics for the matched sample are reported in Panel D of Table 1. Relative to the Preqin database and SPI itself, the deals? returns range widely and appear representative.15  

Additional Data Sources. For supplemental analysis, we use data on stock returns from CRSP, data on conventional acquisitions from CapitalIQ, data on public firms from Compustat which we use to identify public debt recapitalizations, and data on funds from Preqin's ESG module. These are introduced where they are used.  

## 2 Empirical Approach  

We are interested in the causal effect of LBOs on employee outcomes. The two major analytical challenges are non-random selection of targets by acquirers and non-random selection of employees into writing reviews. To address the first issue, we use a differences-in-differences design, test for pre-trends using an event study, test for targeting drivers, and conduct a falsification test with canceled deals. While there are likely unobservables that drive PE targeting, these steps support causality within the treated population. To address the second challenge, we construct measures at the company level, focus on cross-group heterogeneity, and test and control for composition changes in characteristics of interest.  

Our baseline test is described by Equation (1) and is a differences-in-differences specification at the company-quarter level. The first difference compares targets before and after the buyout. The second difference compares targets to firms that were never PE-owned.  

$$
\bar{Y}_{j,q}=\beta\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Post}\mathrm{Deal}_{j,q})+\alpha_{j}+\gamma_{n,q}+\varepsilon_{j,q}.
$$  

$\bar{Y}_{j,q}$ is the quarter $q$ average of a particular outcome for company $j$ in industry $n$ , such as the average compensation rating given to Dell Technologies in 2012Q3. The indicator variable $\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Post}\mathrm{Deal}_{j,q})$ is one if firm $j$ is PE-owned in quarter $q$ and zero if not. The coefficient of interest, $\beta$ , captures the relationship between the PE ownership and $\bar{Y}_{j,q}$ . We use company fixed effects $(\alpha_{j})$ to control for cross-company differences and industry-quarter fixed effects $(\gamma_{n,q})$ to control for industry-level time trends. We use only reviews from employees who report working for the firm at the time of their review.  

To understand how different types of employees are impacted, we construct company-by-quarter-by-cohort average outcomes, $\bar{Y}_{j,q,c}$ , and test the interaction of the deal effect with the cohort characteristic. For example, to study short- vs. long-tenured employees, we calculate the average outcome at the company-quarter level separately for these two groups of employees. Then we use the model in Equation (2) to assess the interaction effect, where $X_{c}$ represents an indicator for whether the group is composed of short- or long-tenured employees and $\delta$ , our coefficient of interest, represents the differential effect on that group.  

$$
\bar{Y}_{j,q,c}=\delta\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Post}\mathrm{Deal}_{j,q})\times X_{c}+\beta\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Post}\mathrm{Deal}_{j,q})+\omega X_{c}+\alpha_{j}+\gamma_{n,q}+\varepsilon_{j,q,c}.
$$  

We also use event studies to test the identifying assumption that target and control companies would continue on parallel trends in the absence of the buyout. We plot the coefficients $\beta_{s}$ from the following equation:  

$$
Y_{i}=\sum_{s\neq-1}\beta_{s}\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Deal~in~}q-s\mathrm{~Quarter}_{j,q,s})+\alpha_{j}+\gamma_{n,q}+\varepsilon_{i}.
$$  

Here, $\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Deal~in}q-s\mathrm{~Quarter}_{j,q,s})$ is an indicator variable equal to one if an LBO of company $j$ occurred $s$ quarters prior to quarter $q$ and zero otherwise. The quarter before the deal is omitted.16 In supplementary tests, we conduct the main analysis at the review level, which weights larger firms more heavily (note the main model weights all company-quarters equally).  

## 3 Effect of LBOs on Job Quality  

One of our main contributions is to test the effect of LBOs on the job quality of current employees. In Table 2, we show that LBOs have strong negative effects on all four satisfaction dimensions. Employees satisfaction with compensation declines by 0.083 rating points after a buyout (column (1). This is economically significant; for example, it is $57\%$ larger than the 0.053 gap we see between jobs that typically require a college degree and jobs that require only high school (Section 5). As a second benchmark, the effect is equivalent to the satisfaction decrease associated with $33\%$ lower IRR (Section 4). LBOs have a similar negative effect on employee perceptions of the firm's culture (column (3)); to our knowledge, this offers the first evidence of how PE affects corporate culture. The negative effects on work-life balance and senior management are slightly smaller (columns (2) and (4)). Surprisingly, we find no effects on pay (columns (5)-(7), and the discrepancy does not reflect a cut to benefits.17 In Section 5, we propose a mechanism to explain why, if LBO investors do not reduce pay, we would see a decline in satisfaction with compensation.  

We use Equation (3) to test the identification assumption that LBO targets were not already on track to experience declines in employee satisfaction, in which case the declines should start before the LBO. The results, in Figure 3, contain no pre-trends for any of the four measures both for the overall sample (left) and the high leverage sample (right). There are clear, persistent decreases in satisfaction in the quarters immediately after the buyout quarter. Consistent with the regressions, the most marked changes are for compensation and culture. Event studies for reported pay also show no pre-trends (Appendix Figure A.3).  

Layoffs.  An immediate question is whether the results reflect layoffs. Although it is commonly asserted that LBOs are associated with layoffs, the academic evidence is conficted.18 We use a novel LinkedIn panel (see Section 1) to understand whether layoffs occur in our setting and the extent layoffs drive our results. Appendix Figure A.4 Panel A shows that the departure rate increases in the first year after the buyout and returns to baseline during the second year. There is no increase in the hiring rate (Panel B), and therefore the overall employment growth rate declines (Panel C). These patterns also appear in the number of reviews, where there is some evidence of a short-term decline in the number of reviews by current employees (Appendix Figure A.5 Panel A) and increases in the number of reviews by former employees (Panel B). After the first two quarters, however, the number of reviews reverts to the previous level. Therefore, LBOs do not affect the aggregate number of current employee reviews (Appendix Table A.5 column (6).  

We take several steps to prevent layof-induced composition changes from biasing our results.  

First, we drop former employees from our main analysis to prevent an increase in unhappy recently-laid-off employees driving our results. Second, in Appendix Table A.6 we show that "high-layoff’ deals, with above-median changes in the LinkedIn departure rates between the four years prior to and after the deal, do not lead to satisfaction changes that are statistically different from low-layoff deals. We do the same for our key heterogeneity tests by adding a layoff interaction. Third, we show that long-term changes drive our key results. Fourth, in Panel A of Table 3, we consider data on former employees separately and show they have a similar-sized negativeeffect.19 Finally, in Section 6.2 we explicitly test for changes in observable characteristics.  

In sum, while one-time layoffs occur and may drive some of the negative effects on average satisfaction, they perhaps surprisingly do not appear to have first-order effects on the remaining employees. Our results appear for LBO targets that are not subject to layoffs, our measured satisfaction decreases persist long after the immediate layoffs (comparing Figure 3 and Appendix Figure A.4), and the LBO-associated layoffs themselves do not dramatically increase current employees’ propensity to review.  It remains possible that lower satisfaction stems from a permanent decrease in job security, which would represent a genuine decrease in job quality.  

## 4 Risk Sharing  

Incentive alignment is one of the key ways PE managers claim to add value. We examine three ways in which private-equity transactions can impact owner-employee risk sharing. First, we show that LBOs increase the sensitivity of employee compensation satisfaction to LBO investor returns. Second, we show that our LBO effects are driven by high leverage deals. Third, we show direct evidence of an increase in managerial incentive pay and an offsetting decline in reported work-life  

### 4.1  Investor Returns  

Do employees win when LBO investors win? Edmans (2011) and others have shown that higher returns coincide with more satisfied employees for public firms, but PE could have different effects for several reasons. If investor returns in PE come largely from extracting employee surplus, we might see a negative relationship between returns and job quality changes - the more effective PE is at extracting surplus, the worse workers do. Alternatively, there might be no correlation if PE firms always extract employee surplus in the same way regardless of the deal success. Finally, we might see a positive relationship if there is a risk-sharing mechanism in which investor successes and failures are passed through to employees, similar to the way that currency exchange rate variation passes through to wages and prices (Gopinath, Itskhoki, and Rigobon, 2010; Bussiere, 2013). Since deal performance is determined well after the deal date and occurs simultaneously with satisfaction changes, we do not seek to establish causality here.20  

Satisfaction and Deal Returns. We first show the raw relationship between returns and job quality changes for the return-matched deals. Figure 4 uses bin-scatters to show there is a positive association between investor returns and changes in employee satisfaction, particularly for changes in compensation and for IRR. Figure 5 shows that while there is no relationship for base pay, there is a markedly positive slope for variable earnings across all three return measures.  

Next, we examine this association after removing company- and time-specific confounders using the following linear regression model:  

$$
\Delta\bar{Y}_{j}=\beta\mathrm{Return}_{j}+\omega\mathrm{X}_{j}+\eta_{t}+\varepsilon_{j}.
$$  

Here, there is no causal interpretation and we attempt to identify only the residual correlation between investor outcomes and the changes in job quality at the target firm. The dependant variable $\Delta\bar{Y}_{j}$ is the change in average ratings from before to afer the LBO, with both ratings adjusted for industry-quarter fixed effects. The vector $\mathrm{X}_{j}$ controls for the pre-deal average rating (to demean each firm's outcome) and the investment amount. Finally, we include deal year fixed effects, $\eta_{t}$  

The estimates are presented in Table 4 Panel A. We use IRR, which is most closely tied to a buyout fund GPs’ carry (Robinson and Sensoy, 2013; Gredil, 2021) and is traditionally the central evaluation metric for both deals and GPs (Gompers, Kaplan, and Mukharlyamov, 2016; Da Rin and Phalippou, 2017).2 Panel A shows a large and robust positive relationship for all satisfaction measures and for incentive pay measures. For example, a $10\%$ increase in the annualized return is associated with a $7\%$ increase in employee variable pay (column (6)). The exception is base earnings (column (5)), where we see no effect. Appendix Table A.7 shows the same pattern for the other two return measures: TVM, which captures the total return to investors without any time or risk adjustment (Panel A), and PME, which captures idiosyncratic returns after accounting for what the comparable public market investments would deliver (Panel B). Appendix Table A.8 shows that the relationship is stronger in fully resolved deals but is similar for deals that were not yet fully resolved at the end of our sample. Furthermore, we find no relationship between the average pre-deal ratings and the deal returns, both raw and as a percentile rank within the fund (Appendix Table A.9).  

Overall, it is clear that higher investor returns in LBOs are not associated with larger deteriorations in employee ratings. Instead of a zero-sum reallocation of employee surplus to investors, there instead appears to be a positive relationship, and the deals that are worst for job quality are also worst for investors.  

Relative to Matched Public Firm Investments.  An association between LBO deal returns and employee satisfaction is perhaps not surprising, as public firms show a similar relationship (Edmans, 2011). This leads us to ask whether the relationship between financial performance and job quality for PE-backed firms is different from that in public firms. The positive association between returns and job quality could be weaker for PE-backed firms if PE investors are less capital constrained on the downside and more effective at keeping rents to themselves in the upside. It could be stronger if PE firms give more performance pay on the upside and pass more downside to employees through leverage, a greater willingness to fire, or costly default.  

We compare the sensitivity of public and private firms by creating a set of “mimicking” public trades for each PE deal. Our approach has two steps. First, we match each LBO target to at most the five closest publicly traded peers at the time of the deal.22 Second, for each public company we construct a hypothetical trade that mimics the cash flow pattern of the respective LBO. We follow Korteweg and Nagel (2016) and assume that investment amounts in the mimicking deals exactly match those of the actual deals, the interim distributions are a function of the time since the deal or previous distribution, and the residual value is paid off at the terminal distribution of the actual deal. Deviating from Korteweg and Nagel (2016), we use an individual stock's return rather than market-wide returns, so our mimicking trades capture both idiosyncratic and systematic risk, just as the comparable LBO's returns.  

These mimicking trades “package”’ public stock returns in PE-like cash flows. We can use them to calculate comparable IRRs, TVMs, and PMEs against style and industry sectors, just as we do for the actual LBO sponsor fund cash flows. We can then estimate the sensitivity of satisfaction to returns for LBO targets relative to public companies:  

$$
\Delta\bar{Y}_{j}=\beta\mathrm{Return}_{j}+\delta\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{LBO}_{j})\times\mathrm{Return}_{j}+\gamma\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{LBO}_{j})+\omega\mathrm{X}_{j}+\alpha_{d}+\varepsilon_{j}.
$$  

The coefficient of interest $\delta$ is on the interaction between the return measure and being an LBO rather than a mimicking trade. Each LBO and mimicking trade is a separate observation in the regression, with fixed effects $(\alpha_{d})$ entering for each group of an LBO target and associated mimicking trades and other variables being as described above.  

We present the results in Table 4 Panel B.23 Better performance is associated with more satisfied employees across measures and for both public and private companies. Looking first at raw performance in the odd columns, the compensation satisfaction of employees at LBO targets is more related to investor returns than for public companies. Specifically, a 0.25 increase in log  

IRR is associated with a 0.095 point increase in employee ratings of compensation, about three times as large as the 0.033 increase for the mimicking public investments. Decreases in satisfaction are correspondingly more severe. Even columns show the same results for IRR percentile rank, which adjust for the higher mean and volatility of LBO returns (Appendix Table 1 Panel D).  

Note that the higher pass-through to compensation relative to public companies co-exists with lower satisfaction on average after LBOs; the coefcient on LBO independently of -0.22 implies that the LBO investor returns would need to be at least 1.1 standard deviations above the sample mean for the target's employees to experience a larger increase in satisfaction than if they were working for a comparable public company with the same stock return. Whereas the estimates in column (2) imply that the expected increase in LBO employee satisfaction is lower than that of a median public firm benchmark for deals returning below the 74th percentile investors. Importantly, the results in Table 4 are not plausibly driven by pre-deal employee satisfaction ratings, as shown in Appendix Table A.9. Finally, we show that for all models in Panel B, there is significant, positive LBO pass-through as in Panel A even though they are not significantly different from the public companies (p-values for the F-test on the sum of Return and LBO $\times$ Return).  

In sum, the negative changes in employee satisfaction after buyouts are endemic (but not limited) to low-performing deals for investors.24 LBOs exhibit more pass-through of returns to employee satisfaction with compensation than publicly traded firms (though they have a lower average), consistent with surplus-sharing theories. This could arise from more use of explicit performance-based employment contracts or could reflect another mechanism. However, we find no evidence that pre-deal employee satisfaction ratings explain the variation in returns to LBO investors. While these correlations shed light on how PE creates value, we reiterate that there is no sense of causal determination.  

### 4.2  Deal Leverage  

High leverage is a key point of differentiation for LBOs relative to other transaction types such as M&A and growth equity. It magnifies both returns and the risk of financial distress and is seen as central to value creation in PE (Kaplan and Stromberg, 2009; Guo, Hotchkiss, and Song, 2011). We measure leverage as the value of new debt taken on in the deal relative to the deal size, enabling us to assess the change in job quality (left-hand side of the equation) as a function of the change in debt relative to firm value (right-hand side of the equation). We do not observe total debt, but this is less interesting because it does not get at the change associated with the buyout.  

We study whether leverage is related to a deal's effect on employees by separating the independent variable $\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Post}\mathrm{LBO}_{j,q})$ in  Equation(1) into  multiple  variables representing different levels of a deal characteristic. This allows us to interpret the coefficients relative to the base group of non-target control firms (in supplementary tests, we assess whether coefcients are statistically different from one another). We first divide the sample of LBOs around median leverage in Table 5 Panel A. High-leverage deals drive the negative effects on job satisfaction. This is most extreme for culture, where we see that the effect is zero for below-median leverage deals and -0.14 for above-median leverage deals, and for compensation, where the effect of above-median leverage deals is about twice as large. The differential leverage effect is always economically significant and is statistically significant for compensation and work-life balance (Appendix Table A.11). The effects increase roughly monotonically in leverage. In Panel B of Table 5, we divide the sample into quartiles. The magnitude is consistently lowest for the first quartile, and generally increases, with the negative results driven by the third and fourth quartiles. In Panel C, we show strong negative effects of an interaction with continuous leverage. (In unreported results, we find no effect of a quadratic term.) The last three columns of the table suggest weak evidence of pay increases in low-leverage deals.  

We repeat our main event study analysis for the LBO sample for deals with above-median leverage and present the results on the right side of Figure 3. Despite the smaller sample size, we clearly see that the discontinuous declines after the deal are much stronger for the high leverage deals in the right-hand graphs than for the overall sample in the left-hand graphs. Although leverage is endogenous and associated with other factors, the event studies suggest high leverage deals have a causal effect, and show that high-leverage deals do not target firms with pre-trends.  

We also rule out several alternative explanations that might plausibly be correlated with leverage. First, an association with layoffs does not seem to drive the leverage effect and, in fact, controlling for layoffs seems to strengthen the leverage results (Appendix Table A.12). Second, in Appendix B we show other deal-level variables are only weakly predictive and thus cannot explain our leverage results.  These analyses include dividing the LBO sample into three transaction types: public-to-private deals, corporate divestitures, and vanilla LBOs. The negative effects are of roughly similar magnitude across the three deal types and are not significantly different from one another. The exception is that corporate divestitures are associated with larger work-life balance declines - where employees at the targeted subsidiary may have previously benefited from managers who enjoyed the “quiet life” and suffered from the agency issues inherent in multiunit corporations (Scharfstein and Stein, 2000; Schoar, 2002; Bertrand and Mullainathan, 2003) - but the results are weak relative to the leverage channel. Deal size has no strong effect, alleviating concerns about size leading to biases in debt availability. Finally, fund ESG status does not make a major difference and LBOs led by ESG funds are associated with the same negative effect on employees as other deals. In sum, although we cannot rule out the possibility that an omitted variable drives the leverage relationship, we show that common deal-level characteristics do not drive it.  

### 4.3  Managerial Compensation  

PE sponsors often claim that they create value through stronger incentives. Our data allow us to directly measure incentive pay, for both frontline workers and managers. The managers in these review data are generally lower- and mid-level, rather than C-suite executives. In Table 6 we show that managers enjoy a dramatic increase in performance pay after an LBO, on both the intensive margin where they receive $43\%$ higher performance pay (column (6)) and the extensive margin (column (7)) where they are about five percentage points ( $18\%$ of the mean) more likely to get any performance pay. This pay increase is isolated to incentive pay, with base pay going up only slightly (column (5)). In Appendix Table A.13, we break down performance pay into its four component categories and show this effect is driven by cash bonuses rather than stock or profit sharing.  

Perhaps because of these stronger incentives, managers report larger declines in work-life balance (column (2)) and, in fact, drive the entire negative effect of LBOs on work-life balance. For the other satisfaction dimensions, managers are not differentially affected relative to frontline workers. Therefore, after LBOs, managers are pushed to work harder but are compensated more generously, particularly via incentive pay. This is consistent with findings by Gompers, Kaplan, and Mukharlyamov (2016) about the importance of incentives in PE deals. More generally, higher incentive compensation for managers in particular is related to the increase in overall within-firm pay inequality (Piketty, 2013) and also a greater connection between higher and more volatile pay for managers and higher firm productivity (Bloom et al., 2021). Our results suggest that the dramatically increasing footprint of the LBO business model may in part be responsible for these trends.  

The rise in manager incentive pay raises the possibility that LBOs reduce satisfaction with compensation by increasing within-firm pay inequality (Bandiera, Barankay, and Rasul, 2007; Breza, Kaur, and Shamdasani, 2017). To assess whether this may be the case, we construct three standard measures of within-firm pay inequality: the standard deviation, 90-10 ratio, and 90-50 ratio, all at the company-quarter level. We first examine whether LBOs increase inequality in either base pay or total pay. Appendix Table A.14 Panel A shows that there is no statistically significant effect within our data, though the coefficients are positive and larger when we include incentive pay. Next, we create an indicator for LBOs that have above-median changes in inequality. Panel B shows these deals do not have different effects from deals with below-median inequality changes (the interaction coefficients are near-zero and insignificant). Therefore, higher within-firm inequality does not appear to explain the overall decline in satisfaction.  

## 5 Models of Risk Sharing  

Since the rise of agency theory, the degree to which employees and employers share risk has been a topic of great interest (Ross, 1973; Holmstrom, 1979). Intuitively, exposing employees to greater risk, whether through incentive pay, firm leverage, or profit sharing, can strengthen incentives and increase productivity (Lazear, 2000). At the same time, employees are generally more risk averse than the firm, and incentive pay increases the risks that employees bear. Higher leverage increases the chances of firm distress, which leads to layoffs, which in turn imposes large costs on workers who are not fully insured and face large switching costs to find an equivalent job (Cantor et al., 1990; Asquith, Gertner, and Scharfstein, 1994; Sharpe, 1994). Under risk bearing models, workers demand compensating wage differentials to offset that risk (Abowd and Ashenfelter, 1981; Hamermesh and Wolfe, 1990).  

This logic can help explain capital structure. Theoretically, Titman (1984), Chang (1992), and Berk, Stanton, and Zechner (2010) show that since financial distress - in particular firm liquidation - is costly to workers, firms should choose a debt level below that which maximizes the firm's financial value. Empirical work in support of this view includes Chemmanur, Cheng, and Zhang (2013), Agrawal and Matsa (2013), and Simintzi, Vig, and Volpin (2015).  

Ex-ante, a firm may wish to commit to low leverage and stable pay to attract workers. In the Berk, Stanton, and Zechner (2010) model, the firm pays a risk-averse worker a wage that never falls unless the firm is in distress, but rises with good news about worker productivity (following Harris and Holmstrom (1982). This leads to entrenchment where workers are on average paid above the competitive market wage. Importantly, the employee's surplus is positively related to her tenure. If the firm is liquidated, the worker must take a large pay cut in her new job. When the firm takes on more debt and thereby increases the chance of liquidation, the firm compensates workers for risk by raising pay. In turn, higher labor costs lead the firm to have below-optimal debt, which leads to a persistent clientele effect where some firms have sub-optimally low leverage and attract particularly risk-averse employees.  

Berk, Stanton, and Zechner (2010) and related models rely on firms upholding an implicit contract between shareholders and workers. LBO investors may exploit an arbitrage opportunity: With the decline in unions and labor power generally, modern labor markets may not require firms to abide by the implicit contract. Previously, the firm may have done so because incumbent managers and shareholders faced some inertia or enjoyed private benefits from employee welfare. LBO investors may target firms that are under-levered from the perspective of incentives or the tax benefits of debt. They increase leverage dramatically, but do not increase pay as the implicit contract would require, a breach of implicit contracts along the lines of Shleifer and Summers (1988).  

This mechanism has three key implications, which we test in turn. First, higher leverage requires a compensating differential, which leads workers to feel underpaid when leverage increases in an LBO without a corresponding pay increase. Second, post-LBO hires are not impacted by these changes because they did not suffer a contract breach - they are fairly paid given the risk they take on. Third, the model predicts larger effects for workers with longer tenure and generally more “slack,” in the sense that their current job is preferred to their outside options.  

Reduced Compensation Satisfaction without Reduced Compensation. We showed a decline in compensation satisfaction despite no measurable change in base pay. Although perhaps initially puzzling, these results are entirely consistent with theories of costly employee risk-bearing. If workers are risk-averse, they demand higher wages from firms that are more likely to fall into financial distress. Post buyout, non-managers earn the same pay at a riskier firm, so they perceive themselves to be underpaid relative to their new job and new risk.  

These compensation results are harder to square with other models of leverage impacting employees. For example, in some contexts firms strategically increase leverage to extract wage concessions from labor (Perotti and Spier, 1993; Matsa, 2010).25 These models generally predict lower wages overall but do not provide clear predictions on passthrough, while we find no average wage change but large increases in passthrough, including much higher incentive pay for managers. Therefore, in the LBO case it does not seem that new owners are using leverage as a  

strategic bargaining tool.  

New Hires.  Comparing how LBOs impact new hires versus existing employees offers a further test. Under a Shleifer and Summers (1988)-style breach of implicit contracts, existing employees will be hurt but new hires ought to be unaffected. On the other hand, generally employee-unfriendly operational changes would impact both pre-existing employees and new hires, relative to both groups at control firms.  

We attempt to differentiate between these in Panel B of Table 3 by comparing the effect of an LBO on current employees who started after the PE deal (new hires) with current employees who started before the deal (pre-deal employees), using review-level data.26 The first row of coefcients documents large negative effects among current employees who were hired before the deal. Adding these to the significant, positive coefficients for new hires in the second row indicates that new hires are unaffected. This points away from employee-unfriendly operational changes as a mechanism because these should affect new hires as well.  

Employee Slack.  An increase in risk sharing would have the largest effect on employees with the most to lose, either because they have worse outside options or because they are entrenched and have captured more surplus.  We consider different measures of this slack, looking at characteristics that would predict outside options and entrenchment. Perhaps the most natural measure of outside options is labor market conditions. If unemployment is relatively high, workers face higher costs to job loss and thus higher costs of firm risk. We assess whether the effects are stronger when the industry has a higher unemployment rate in Table 7. Indeed, we see that the effects on compensation (column(1) and culture (column (3)) are twice as large in industry-years with above-median unemployment, consistent with risk being more costly when workers have worse outside options.27  

Next, we consider job tenure, which is related both to switching costs and entrenchment. We divide the current employees into those with less than three years and those with more than three years of tenure at the firm. In Table 8, we show that the results for all four satisfaction dimensions are driven by workers with longer tenure. The coefficients are near zero for short-tenure workers, while long-tenured workers experience large negative effects. For example, the negative effect on compensation is over $10\%$ of a standard deviation for long-tenured workers (column (1). This result is robust to using review-level data and to controlling for skill. In Appendix Table A.15 Panel A, we report the results at the review level, now exploiting the higher power to consider four tenure categories. We find that in general, the most negative effects are among workers with at least four years of tenure, though there are also significant negative effects among workers with 2- 3 years of tenure. In Panel B, we find that these results are essentially unaffected when we include controls for worker education, experience, and manager fixed effects.  

Our final employee characteristics are proxies for skill. Unskilled workers are arguably the losers in the current changing economy, facing pressure from automation and the rise of gig labor. For example, Araujo et al. (2021) show they face the largest costs from employer bankruptcies. To test whether these workers are more negatively impacted, in Table 9 Panel A we compare effects across jobs that typically require less and more than three years of experience and in Panel B we compare the effects across jobs based on the education level typically required. The negative effects on compensation, culture, and senior management are generally driven by lower-skill workers (columns (1), (3), and (4)), while the negative effect on work-life balance is driven by higher-skill workers (column (2)), consistent with the relationship for managers. We also see an increase in base pay, of about $3\%$ , for higher-skill workers (column (5)), and a positive albeit insignificant coefficient on variable pay.  

In these tables, the independent average effects of the characteristics offer benchmarks for assessing the magnitude of the negative effect of LBOs. For example, people in jobs that require a college degree are about 0.10 rating points more satisfied with their firm's culture (Table 9 Panel B column (3). Therefore, the average negative effect of LBOs on satisfaction with culture, at -0.09 rating points, represents nearly the average difference in satisfaction with culture associated with a college degree. To provide a second benchmark, this negative effect is about half the average extra satisfaction that managers have with firm culture relative to non-managers (which is 0.2 rating points, from Table 6 column (3)).  

In sum, the decline in satisfaction with pay is concentrated among less-skilled, entry-level workers and those who have been at the firm for a longer period. To the extent these workers would be hurt more by risk, this supports our risk based explanation.  

## 6 Validation and Robustness Tests  

In this section, we conduct an array of tests that validate and confirm our main results. First, we show LBOs are distinct from other types of deals. Second, we show our results are robust to employee composition changes.  Finally, we show our results are robust to a variety of specifications.  

### 6.1 Other Deal Types  

Recapitalizations. Since leverage is endogenous, our leverage results could reflect something about high-leverage LBOs that is not related to new debt.28 To further test the importance of leverage for job quality, we consider situations outside of PE where firms quickly take on large amounts of new debt. We focus on recapitalizations, which occur when a public firm increases its leverage by issuing debt while simultaneously buying back shares or issuing large dividends (Kovenock and Phillips, 1997). There are several reasons for these transactions, including fending off a hostile takeover and facilitating the exit of a large shareholder. Using Compustat data, we define recapitalizations as occurring when a firm increases debt by at least $5\%$ of assets while at the same time buying back shares and paying out cash worth a combined total of more than $5\%$ assets.29 This fiter captures large capital structure changes, with the average transaction leading to a $37\%$ increase in book leverage from a $22\%$ debt issue, an $8\%$ share buyback, and an $8\%$ dividend, all expressed as percentages of firm assets. We match these firms to our Glassdoor data, yielding 258 leveraged recapitalizations during 2010-2016. Although these firms are undergoing large capital structure changes, assets increase just $4\%$ , suggesting much of the change is financial reorganization rather than expansion. We follow the capital structure literature (e.g., Korteweg, Schwert, and Strebulaev (2019) by considering firms whose assets always exceed $\$10$ million.  

Table 10 reports the association between public recapitalizations and changes in our seven job qualitymeasures. Higher-debt  recapitalizations  are  associated  with  larger  decreases  in compensation satisfaction, consistent with our results from LBOs. The coefficient is large and of strikingly similar size to the leverage coefficient on PE deals (Table 5 Panel C). While the effect of leverage may be similar, the overall change is not: buyouts with relatively low levels of debt are associated with no change in compensation satisfaction, while recapitalizations with relatively low levels of debt are associated with an increase. In addition to providing support for a relationship between leverage and compensation satisfaction, this table helps to confirm that there is something particular about LBOs that leads to our suite of effects (further evidence is in our analysis of other deal types below).  

Canceled Deals. A central concern with our main analytical approach is that because PE firms do not target companies at random, there may be unobservables at the targeted firms that would lead them to have the effects we see in the absence of the buyout. This raises the question of what the counterfactual would be in the absence of the deal. Above, we addressed this concern with event studies, which establish that targets were not on track towards the negative effects before the deal. We push our identification further by studying canceled deals. We obtain 110 canceled LBOs from PitchBook and Capital IQ. Appendix Table A.16 Panel A presents summary statistics on reviews for these firms, in the same manner as Table 1 Panel A. Panel B reports the differencesin-differences effect of canceled LBOs on employee satisfaction measures, relative to the same set of control firms as in the main analysis (target firms of LBOs are omitted from the sample). There are no negative effects of canceled LBOs. The coefficients are generally small and insignificant, except for a positive effect at the $10\%$ significance level on Work-Life Balance. This provides  

strong support for our identification assumption.  

Generic Acquisition Restructuring.  The effects of LBOs might be common to acquisitions more generally. To address this, we gather data on conventional acquisitions from Capital IQ to compare their effects to those of PE acquisitions. We require M&A transactions to have a public or private corporate buyer and to occur between 2010 and 2016, have a U.S. target, have a value of $\$100$ million or above, and not be LBO, MBO, or bankruptcy transactions.30 Out of a total of 5,672 deals meeting these requirements, we match 2,040 to Glassdoor.31 Among these, we eliminate deals in which the acquirer did not take a majority stake or where we do not observe reviews by current employees both before and after the deal. This requires acquired companies to become subsidiaries rather than be subsumed into the acquirer and disappear. As a result, the matched deals tend to be large relative to the average acquisition, which is helpful because it makes them more comparable to the LBO targets. This leads to 1,010 M&A deals in the final analysis sample. Summary statistics on these deals are in Appendix Table A.17.  

We present results in Table 11. These models use Equation 1, except the independent variables of interest are post-deal indicators, and should be interpreted relative to control firms that are never acquired, not relative to one another. The first row in Table 11 indicates that LBOs negatively affect all four satisfaction dimensions. In contrast, traditional corporate acquisitions have weaker and mixed effects. Specifically, M&A negatively affects compensation, but with a less precise and smaller magnitude than LBOs. There is a strong negative effect of M&A on senior management ratings, but no effect on work-life balance or culture. The comparison to M&A allows us to conclude that while LBO effects may partially refect generic restructuring after an acquisition, a portion of the negative effect on compensation as well as the effects on the non-pecuniary amenities of work-life balance and culture appear specific to LBOs.  

Other PE Deal Types.  We are interested in whether our main effects reflect simply the event of any PE transaction, or are particular to the mixture of changes - notably a change in control and high leverage - that occur following LBOs. The subsequent rows of Table 11 consider two other deal types. First, MBOs have negative effects on compensation, but no effects on the other three dimensions. Recall that in an MBO, the existing managers of a company purchase a controlling interest in a company with the help of a PE firm. While leverage increases, management is generally constant, helping to explain the zero effect on senior management.  

In a growth equity deal, the PE firm takes a non-majority stake in a company to fund new investment. If the LBO effects are common to any new investment, we expect to see similar results for growth equity, but the bottom row of the table shows that these deals have no effects. Overall, deals characterized by increases in leverage (LBO and MBO) experience the largest declines in satisfaction with compensation.  

### 6.2  Employee Composition and Distribution Effects  

Our results could potentially be driven by changes to employee composition around LBOs. We examine whether this is the case in Appendix Figure A.6, where we plot changes in our employee characteristics around the time of the deal. These charts show no obvious deal effects, something we confirm in Appendix Table A.5. In unreported tests, we control for five aspects of employee composition in our deal- and company-level analysis and find that while the sample size is reduced, the results are robust to including all of the measures or any subset.32  

The company-quarter level analysis further obviates concerns about composition changes along the dimensions we study; for example that fewer managers submit reviews after the buyout and managers are in general correlated with higher ratings. This is because the data are constructed as the average review for each cohort (e.g. managers vs. non-managers) after vs. before the buyout and relative to the difference across cohorts at control firms. Therefore, it does not seem that the employee heterogeneity factors explain the results.  

A related concern is that the results could refect a shift in the tail of the satisfaction distribution at LBO targets, with no effect in the middle of the distribution. Appendix Figure A.7 presents quantile regression estimates of the effect of LBOs on four dimensions of employee satisfaction at 5 different quantiles (5th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 95th). The coefficients of $\mathbb{1}(\mathrm{Post}\mathrm{LBO})$ are all negative at different points of the satisfaction distribution, though we see different magnitudes of the effect. The results are not driven by a change to the tail of the distribution but rather to declines across all percentiles, but especially the middle and upper-middle.  

### 6.3 Robustness Checks  

Our results are robust to several alternative specifications. In the interests of space, we discuss these in Online Appendix C. Specifically, we show our results are robust to a matching estimator, do not appear to be driven by endogenous target selection, and hold for different aggregation methods, different cuts of the sample, and additional rating measures.  

## 7 Conclusion  

This paper offers the first analysis, to our knowledge, of the effect of PE buyouts on job quality as perceived by employees. We show that LBOs are associated with significant perceived declines in job quality and increases in managerial incentive pay. In contrast to a narrative of broad-based cost-cutting, we find no effects on average pay. Instead, risk transfer appears to play a central role, with LBOs leading to more return passthrough to employees than at comparable public firms. Relatedly, relatively high leverage LBOs appear to have much stronger negative effects.  

Our results are consistent with risk-averse employees reporting job quality declines due to a perceived loss of promised job security. As further tests of this, we show that predictors of worker entrenchment and unemployment cost, such as industry unemployment rates, long job tenure, and low skill, are associated with larger negative job quality effects. Although immediate post-deal layoffs doubtless contribute to feelings of insecurity, they do not drive our effects.  

Overall, this paper sheds new light on how PE affects the nature of the firm, pushing beyond the existing literature on employment, separations, and wages. LBOs appear to reallocate surplus away from more replaceable and entrenched employees and achieve better matches with new hires. Our results point to a need for further research on how ownership type affects employees, potentially using alternative measures of culture and comprehensive measures of compensation. Another important venue for future research is disentangling the role of ex-ante commitment by PE sponsors to sharing gains with the LBO target employees from the ex-post incentive pay (and perk) hikes if the deal turned very successful.

# Appendix B: Deal Characteristic Analysis For Online Publication  

Deal Type and Size  We examine two other important deal characteristics in Appendix Table B.1. First, we divide the LBO sample into three transaction types: public-to-private deals, corporate divestitures, and vanilla LBOs. The results, in Panel A, show that the negative effects are of roughly similar magnitude across the three deal types, and except for one, they are not significantly different from one another. The outlier is work-life balance, where corporate divestitures show a negative effect that is more than three times as large as vanilla LBOs. The coefficient of -0.158 represents $14\%$ of a standard deviation (Panel A column (2)) and is significantly more negative than other LBOs (Appendix Table B.2 Panel A column (2)). Therefore, corporate divestitures are primarily responsible for a large share of the efficiencies in which employees are asked to work harder, and are also the largest source of negative effects on compensation. In these types of deals, employees at the targeted subsidiary may have previously benefited from managers who enjoyed the “"quiet life” and suffered from the agency issues inherent in multiunit corporations (Scharfstein and Stein, 2000; Bertrand and Mullainathan, 2003). For example, Schoar (2002) argues that “conglomerates dissipate rents in the form of higher wages.?"  

The next characteristic is deal size. We define small as the bottom two terciles and large as the top tercile, though the results are similar using alternative deal size breakdowns. The results, shown in Appendix Table B.1 Panel B, indicate that the main effect is robust across both smaller and larger deals. However, there are more adverse effects on culture in smaller deals (column (3)). The effects on satisfaction with worklife balance and senior management are larger among bigger deals (columns (2) and (4)). These results combined with the corporate divestiture results from Panel A support the idea that as firms become larger and more diversified, employees are not required to work as hard, creating opportunities for an external acquirer (Seru, 2014).  

ESG and Impact Funds  Creating a positive social impact is an increasingly important priority for institutional investors, with the share of managed assets in the U.S. that are under ESG mandates as much as doubling since 2015 to represent $\$17$ trillion or a third of the total.3 Labor relations are central to the "social’ component of ESG (Henisz, Koller, and Nuttall, 2019). We examine whether deals led by funds with ESG or Impact investment mandates show different effects.  

To do so, we acquired Preqin's ESG module, which includes measures of ESG status for nearly 37,000 PE funds. We are able to match $48\%$ of the Glassdoor-Pitchbook deals’ funds to Preqin's funds, resulting $59\%$ of the Glassdoor-Pitchbook deals having at least one fund matched to Preqin's funds. We focus on two categories: ESG and the subset of ESG called “Impact." We classify deals according to the fund classification of the lead investor. The ESG category applies to any fund that reports considering environmental, social, or governance factors in its decision-making. The narrower “Impact’ category includes funds with explicit investment policies to fund frms with positive social impact.34 The Impact label has the stricter requirement that funds provide a formal impact strategy and evidence of compliance. Table 1 Panel C shows that while $13\%$ of the deals in our data are associated with funds that describe themselves as ESG, only $3\%$ are associated with Impact funds.  

We first consider the full set of all ESG funds. As shown in Appendix Table B.3 Panel A, deals led by ESG funds are associated with the same negative effect on employees as other deals. One explanation is that fund ESG status is self-reported and notoriously poorly measured, which can enable funds to label themselves as ESG-oriented even if they are not.35 Regardless, our results indicate that if limited partners wished to screen firms on treating employees well (as measured by the employees? own perceptions), they cannot achieve this by screening only on a broad ESG category. As labor relations become an increasing priority among limited partners, this potentially points to the need for new measures and sources of data.36  

We next focus on the Impact indicator, which represents the narrow category of investments by funds that, according to Preqin, require portfolio companies to have a positive impact. In Appendix Table B.3 Panel B, we document that our negative results are driven by non-Impact funds. There is no measurable effect of buyouts on employee satisfaction when the investment fund has an Impact orientation. Although this sample is small and our coefficients imprecise, it points to potential benefits from more stringent screens.
